explanations.machine learning: The paper proposes a three-way decision method and a sample-weighted support vector data description (SW-SVDD) model for credit risk prediction, which are machine learning techniques.
explanations.supervised learning: The study involves predicting the default status of samples, which is a supervised learning task where the model learns from labeled data.
explanations.classification: The paper focuses on classifying samples into default and nondefault categories, which is a classification problem.
explanations.support vector machine: The paper constructs a new sample-weighted support vector data description (SW-SVDD) model, which is a variant of the support vector machine (SVM) technique.
explanations.SVM: The SW-SVDD model mentioned in the paper is based on the support vector machine (SVM) methodology.
